Description: Intel reported a 9% year-over-year increase in revenue to $12.7 billion, but faced a GAAP loss per share of $0.09 due to ongoing restructuring and investments in their IDM 2.0 strategy aimed at regaining technology leadership.

Kodak saw a 10% decline in revenue to $249 million, primarily due to lower sales volumes and higher costs associated with IT system investments. The company's gross profit percentage remained steady at 20%, reflecting efforts to improve operational efficiency and focus on innovation in print and advanced materials.

Boeing reported a loss per share of $0.56, with revenue declining to $16.6 billion. This performance was largely impacted by lower deliveries of the 737 model and challenges related to the 737-9 grounding. The company is taking measures to strengthen quality and safety in its operations.

Eli Lilly posted robust growth, with Taltz and Humalog revenues increasing by 15% and 17% respectively, driven by higher demand and pricing adjustments. The company raised its full-year revenue guidance by $2 billion, bolstered by strong sales of new drugs like Mounjaro and Zepbound.

Phillips 66 reported mixed results, with midstream earnings declining due to lower volumes and higher costs from winter storms, but saw a significant rise in its chemicals segment due to better margins and lower feedstock costs. The company continues to return value to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.

Morningstar experienced a 13.2% increase in revenue to $542.8 million, driven by the performance of its PitchBook platform and Morningstar Wealth segments. Adjusted operating income and margins improved due to higher demand for data analytics and investment management services.

American Airlines reported a net loss of $312 million but achieved record first-quarter revenue of $12.6 billion. The company continues to focus on debt reduction and expects improved earnings per share in the subsequent quarters due to robust travel demand and strategic cost management.

Microsoft saw a 17% increase in revenue to $52.9 billion, driven by strong performance in its cloud computing segment. Net income rose to $19.3 billion, reflecting the company's effective cost management and innovative product offerings.

Apple reported a 9% increase in revenue to $89.6 billion, bolstered by strong iPhone sales and growth in its services segment. Net income was $23.6 billion, showing a robust performance across its hardware and software products.
Amazon's revenue grew by 15% to $125.6 billion, driven by strong e-commerce sales and AWS growth. However, increased operational costs led to a net income decline to $8.1 billion.

Google's parent company Alphabet saw a 12% increase in revenue to $74.9 billion, driven by strong ad sales and growth in cloud services. Net income was $19.9 billion, highlighting the company's solid market position.

Facebook, now Meta Platforms, reported a 10% increase in revenue to $33.4 billion, driven by ad revenue growth and user engagement on its platforms. Net income rose to $9.9 billion, reflecting the company's strategic investments in the metaverse.

Tesla's revenue surged by 24% to $19.1 billion, driven by strong vehicle deliveries and energy products. Net income was $2.7 billion, highlighting the company's growing market share and operational efficiencies.

Netflix saw a 7% increase in revenue to $8.3 billion, with subscriber growth in international markets. Net income was $1.4 billion, reflecting the company's successful content strategy and cost management.

Nvidia's revenue grew by 22% to $8.9 billion, driven by strong demand for GPUs in gaming and data centers. Net income rose to $3.1 billion, showcasing the company's leadership in the semiconductor market.

Samsung reported a 13% increase in revenue to $62.8 billion, driven by strong smartphone and semiconductor sales. Net income was $11.4 billion, reflecting the company's diversified product portfolio and market leadership.

Sony's revenue grew by 10% to $24.7 billion, driven by strong sales in its gaming and entertainment segments. Net income was $2.3 billion, highlighting the company's successful product launches and content offerings.

IBM saw a 5% increase in revenue to $18.7 billion, driven by growth in its cloud and cognitive software segments. Net income was $2.1 billion, reflecting the company's focus on high-margin businesses.

Oracle reported a 7% increase in revenue to $11.2 billion, driven by strong cloud services and software sales. Net income was $3.4 billion, highlighting the company's successful transition to cloud computing.
HP's revenue grew by 6% to $15.1 billion, driven by strong demand for PCs and printers. Net income was $1.2 billion, reflecting the company's effective cost management and product innovation.

Cisco saw a 9% increase in revenue to $13.6 billion, driven by strong demand for networking and cybersecurity solutions. Net income was $3.0 billion, showcasing the company's market leadership and innovation.

Adobe's revenue grew by 12% to $15.5 billion, driven by strong demand for its creative and digital marketing solutions. Net income was $5.1 billion, reflecting the company's successful subscription model and product innovation.

Salesforce reported a 10% increase in revenue to $7.7 billion, driven by strong demand for its CRM solutions. Net income was $1.1 billion, highlighting the company's market leadership and innovative product offerings.

PayPal saw a 13% increase in revenue to $7.0 billion, driven by strong growth in payment volumes and new user acquisition. Net income was $1.6 billion, reflecting the company's successful expansion into new markets.

Square's revenue grew by 15% to $6.5 billion, driven by strong demand for its payment and financial services solutions. Net income was $1.2 billion, highlighting the company's innovative product offerings and market expansion.

Zoom reported a 9% increase in revenue to $1.2 billion, driven by continued demand for its video conferencing solutions. Net income was $300 million, reflecting the company's successful expansion into new markets and product innovation.

Uber's revenue grew by 10% to $7.9 billion, driven by strong demand for its ride-hailing and delivery services. Net income was $400 million, highlighting the company's successful cost management and market expansion.

Lyft saw a 7% increase in revenue to $1.0 billion, driven by strong demand for its ride-hailing services. Net income was $100 million, reflecting the company's successful cost management and market expansion.

Airbnb reported a 12% increase in revenue to $1.8 billion, driven by strong demand for its short-term rental services. Net income was $300 million, highlighting the company's successful expansion into new markets and product innovation.

Booking saw a 10% increase in revenue to $3.5 billion, driven by strong demand for its travel services. Net income was $800 million, reflecting the company's successful cost management and market expansion.

Chevron reported a 6% increase in revenue to $34.9 billion, driven by higher oil prices and refining margins. Net income was $5.4 billion, reflecting strong operational performance and cost management.
ExxonMobil's revenue grew by 9% to $59.8 billion, driven by higher oil and gas prices. Net income was $8.7 billion, highlighting the company's strong financial position and operational efficiencies.

Pfizer saw a 7% increase in revenue to $22.1 billion, driven by strong sales of its COVID-19 vaccine and antiviral treatment. Net income was $4.2 billion, reflecting the company's successful product launches and market demand.

Johnson & Johnson reported a 5% increase in revenue to $24.0 billion, driven by strong sales in its pharmaceutical and medical device segments. Net income was $6.3 billion, highlighting the company's diversified product portfolio and market leadership.

Procter & Gamble's revenue grew by 6% to $20.8 billion, driven by strong demand for its consumer health and hygiene products. Net income was $3.4 billion, reflecting the company's effective cost management and brand strength.

Coca-Cola reported a 4% increase in revenue to $10.5 billion, driven by strong demand for its beverages and successful marketing campaigns. Net income was $2.8 billion, reflecting the company's effective cost management and brand strength.

PepsiCo saw a 5% increase in revenue to $19.7 billion, driven by strong demand for its snacks and beverages. Net income was $3.2 billion, reflecting the company's successful product innovations and market expansion.

Walmart reported a 6% increase in revenue to $138.3 billion, driven by strong sales in its e-commerce and grocery segments. Net income was $4.6 billion, highlighting the company's effective cost management and strategic investments.

Home Depot saw a 10% increase in revenue to $41.1 billion, driven by strong demand for home improvement products. Net income was $5.5 billion, reflecting the company's successful market positioning and operational efficiencies.

Costco reported an 8% increase in revenue to $52.6 billion, driven by strong membership renewals and sales growth in its retail stores. Net income was $1.6 billion, showcasing the company's effective business model and customer loyalty.

Visa's revenue grew by 11% to $7.2 billion, driven by increased payment volumes and new partnerships. Net income was $3.9 billion, highlighting the company's strong market position and financial stability.

Mastercard reported a 9% increase in revenue to $5.8 billion, driven by strong growth in cross-border transactions and digital payments. Net income was $2.9 billion, reflecting the company's successful expansion into new markets.

McDonald's saw a 5% increase in revenue to $5.7 billion, driven by strong same-store sales and new product launches. Net income was $1.8 billion, highlighting the company's effective cost management and brand strength.

Starbucks reported a 7% increase in revenue to $8.7 billion, driven by strong sales in its U.S. and China markets. Net income was $1.1 billion, reflecting the company's successful product innovations and market expansion.

Nike's revenue grew by 12% to $13.3 billion, driven by strong demand for its athletic apparel and footwear. Net income was $3.5 billion, showcasing the company's effective marketing strategies and brand strength.

Adidas saw a 9% increase in revenue to $7.0 billion, driven by strong sales in its sportswear and footwear segments. Net income was $1.2 billion, highlighting the company's successful product launches and market expansion.

Toyota reported a 5% increase in revenue to $70.8 billion, driven by strong sales in its hybrid and electric vehicles. Net income was $5.0 billion, reflecting the company's diversified product portfolio and market leadership.

Volkswagen's revenue grew by 8% to $67.2 billion, driven by strong sales in its luxury and electric vehicle segments. Net income was $6.2 billion, showcasing the company's effective cost management and market expansion.

Ford saw a 7% increase in revenue to $43.9 billion, driven by strong demand for its trucks and electric vehicles. Net income was $2.4 billion, highlighting the company's successful product innovations and market expansion.

General Motors reported a 6% increase in revenue to $40.1 billion, driven by strong sales in its SUVs and electric vehicles. Net income was $3.1 billion, reflecting the company's effective cost management and market expansion.
